instance Amazonka.Data.Log.ToLog Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraintValue.GeoMatchConstraintValue
instance Amazonka.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraintValue.GeoMatchConstraintValue
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraintValue.GeoMatchConstraintValue

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The country from which web requests originate that you want AWS WAF to
--   search for.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newGeoMatchConstraint</a> smart constructor.
data GeoMatchConstraint
GeoMatchConstraint' :: GeoMatchConstraintType -> GeoMatchConstraintValue -> GeoMatchConstraint

-- | The type of geographical area you want AWS WAF to search for.
--   Currently <tt>Country</tt> is the only valid value.
[$sel:type':GeoMatchConstraint'] :: GeoMatchConstraint -> GeoMatchConstraintType

-- | The country that you want AWS WAF to search for.
[$sel:value:GeoMatchConstraint'] :: GeoMatchConstraint -> GeoMatchConstraintValue

-- | Create a value of <a>GeoMatchConstraint</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':GeoMatchConstraint'</a>, <a>geoMatchConstraint_type</a>
--   - The type of geographical area you want AWS WAF to search for.
--   Currently <tt>Country</tt> is the only valid value.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:GeoMatchConstraint'</a>, <a>geoMatchConstraint_value</a>
--   - The country that you want AWS WAF to search for.
newGeoMatchConstraint :: GeoMatchConstraintType -> GeoMatchConstraintValue -> GeoMatchConstraint

-- | The type of geographical area you want AWS WAF to search for.
--   Currently <tt>Country</tt> is the only valid value.
geoMatchConstraint_type :: Lens' GeoMatchConstraint GeoMatchConstraintType

-- | The country that you want AWS WAF to search for.
geoMatchConstraint_value :: Lens' GeoMatchConstraint GeoMatchConstraintValue
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchConstraint.GeoMatchConstraint


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Contains one or more countries that AWS WAF will search for.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newGeoMatchSet</a> smart constructor.
data GeoMatchSet
GeoMatchSet' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> [GeoMatchConstraint] -> GeoMatchSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the GeoMatchSet. You can't change
--   the name of an <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> after you create it.
[$sel:name:GeoMatchSet'] :: GeoMatchSet -> Maybe Text

-- | The <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> for an <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt>
--   (see GeoMatchSet), update a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> (see
--   UpdateGeoMatchSet), insert a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt>
--   or delete one from a <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a
--   <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteGeoMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateGeoMatchSet and by
--   ListGeoMatchSets.
[$sel:geoMatchSetId:GeoMatchSet'] :: GeoMatchSet -> Text

-- | An array of GeoMatchConstraint objects, which contain the country that
--   you want AWS WAF to search for.
[$sel:geoMatchConstraints:GeoMatchSet'] :: GeoMatchSet -> [GeoMatchConstraint]

-- | Create a value of <a>GeoMatchSet</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:GeoMatchSet'</a>, <a>geoMatchSet_name</a> - A friendly
--   name or description of the GeoMatchSet. You can't change the name of
--   an <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> after you create it.
--   
--   <a>$sel:geoMatchSetId:GeoMatchSet'</a>,
--   <a>geoMatchSet_geoMatchSetId</a> - The <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> for an
--   <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt>. You use <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> to get
--   information about a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> (see GeoMatchSet), update a
--   <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateGeoMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> from
--   AWS WAF (see DeleteGeoMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateGeoMatchSet and by
--   ListGeoMatchSets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:geoMatchConstraints:GeoMatchSet'</a>,
--   <a>geoMatchSet_geoMatchConstraints</a> - An array of
--   GeoMatchConstraint objects, which contain the country that you want
--   AWS WAF to search for.
newGeoMatchSet :: Text -> GeoMatchSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the GeoMatchSet. You can't change
--   the name of an <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> after you create it.
geoMatchSet_name :: Lens' GeoMatchSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> for an <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt>
--   (see GeoMatchSet), update a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> (see
--   UpdateGeoMatchSet), insert a <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt>
--   or delete one from a <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a
--   <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteGeoMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateGeoMatchSet and by
--   ListGeoMatchSets.
geoMatchSet_geoMatchSetId :: Lens' GeoMatchSet Text

-- | An array of GeoMatchConstraint objects, which contain the country that
--   you want AWS WAF to search for.
geoMatchSet_geoMatchConstraints :: Lens' GeoMatchSet [GeoMatchConstraint]
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSet.GeoMatchSet


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSetSummary

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and

--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Contains the identifier and the name of the <tt>GeoMatchSet</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newGeoMatchSetSummary</a> smart constructor.
data GeoMatchSetSummary
GeoMatchSetSummary' :: Text -> Text -> GeoMatchSetSummary

--   <tt>GeoMatchSetId</tt> in a GetGeoMatchSet request to get detailed
--   information about an GeoMatchSet.

--   GeoMatchSet.

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.GeoMatchSetUpdate

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Specifies the type of update to perform to an GeoMatchSet with
--   UpdateGeoMatchSet.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newGeoMatchSetUpdate</a> smart constructor.
data GeoMatchSetUpdate
GeoMatchSetUpdate' :: ChangeAction -> GeoMatchConstraint -> GeoMatchSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a country with
--   UpdateGeoMatchSet.
[$sel:action:GeoMatchSetUpdate'] :: GeoMatchSetUpdate -> ChangeAction

-- | The country from which web requests originate that you want AWS WAF to
--   search for.
[$sel:geoMatchConstraint:GeoMatchSetUpdate'] :: GeoMatchSetUpdate -> GeoMatchConstraint

-- | Create a value of <a>GeoMatchSetUpdate</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.

--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:

--   - Specifies whether to insert or delete a country with
--   UpdateGeoMatchSet.
--   
--   <a>$sel:geoMatchConstraint:GeoMatchSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>geoMatchSetUpdate_geoMatchConstraint</a> - The country from which
--   web requests originate that you want AWS WAF to search for.
newGeoMatchSetUpdate :: ChangeAction -> GeoMatchConstraint -> GeoMatchSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a country with
--   UpdateGeoMatchSet.
geoMatchSetUpdate_action :: Lens' GeoMatchSetUpdate ChangeAction

-- | The country from which web requests originate that you want AWS WAF to
--   search for.
geoMatchSetUpdate_geoMatchConstraint :: Lens' GeoMatchSetUpdate GeoMatchConstraint

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The response from a GetSampledRequests request includes an
--   <tt>HTTPHeader</tt> complex type that appears as <tt>Headers</tt> in
--   the response syntax. <tt>HTTPHeader</tt> contains the names and values
--   of all of the headers that appear in one of the web requests that were
--   returned by <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newHTTPHeader</a> smart constructor.
data HTTPHeader
HTTPHeader' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> HTTPHeader

-- | The value of one of the headers in the sampled web request.
[$sel:value:HTTPHeader'] :: HTTPHeader -> Maybe Text

-- | The name of one of the headers in the sampled web request.
[$sel:name:HTTPHeader'] :: HTTPHeader -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>HTTPHeader</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:HTTPHeader'</a>, <a>hTTPHeader_value</a> - The value of
--   one of the headers in the sampled web request.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:HTTPHeader'</a>, <a>hTTPHeader_name</a> - The name of one
--   of the headers in the sampled web request.
newHTTPHeader :: HTTPHeader

-- | The value of one of the headers in the sampled web request.
hTTPHeader_value :: Lens' HTTPHeader (Maybe Text)

-- | The name of one of the headers in the sampled web request.
hTTPHeader_name :: Lens' HTTPHeader (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPHeader.HTTPHeader


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The response from a GetSampledRequests request includes an
--   <tt>HTTPRequest</tt> complex type that appears as <tt>Request</tt> in
--   the response syntax. <tt>HTTPRequest</tt> contains information about
--   one of the web requests that were returned by
--   <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newHTTPRequest</a> smart constructor.
data HTTPRequest
HTTPRequest' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Maybe [HTTPHeader] -> Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> HTTPRequest

-- | The HTTP version specified in the sampled web request, for example,
--   <tt>HTTP/1.1</tt>.
[$sel:hTTPVersion:HTTPRequest'] :: HTTPRequest -> Maybe Text

-- | The two-letter country code for the country that the request
--   originated from. For a current list of country codes, see the
--   Wikipedia entry <a>ISO 3166-1 alpha-2</a>.
[$sel:country:HTTPRequest'] :: HTTPRequest -> Maybe Text

-- | The part of a web request that identifies the resource, for example,
--   <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.
[$sel:uri:HTTPRequest'] :: HTTPRequest -> Maybe Text

-- | A complex type that contains two values for each header in the sampled
--   web request: the name of the header and the value of the header.
[$sel:headers:HTTPRequest'] :: HTTPRequest -> Maybe [HTTPHeader]

-- | The HTTP method specified in the sampled web request. CloudFront
--   supports the following methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>, <tt>GET</tt>,
--   <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and
--   <tt>PUT</tt>.
[$sel:method:HTTPRequest'] :: HTTPRequest -> Maybe Text

-- | The IP address that the request originated from. If the
--   <tt>WebACL</tt> is associated with a CloudFront distribution, this is
--   the value of one of the following fields in CloudFront access logs:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>c-ip</tt>, if the viewer did not use an HTTP proxy or a load
--   balancer to send the request</li>
--   <li><tt>x-forwarded-for</tt>, if the viewer did use an HTTP proxy or a
--   load balancer to send the request</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:clientIP:HTTPRequest'] :: HTTPRequest -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>HTTPRequest</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:hTTPVersion:HTTPRequest'</a>, <a>hTTPRequest_hTTPVersion</a> -
--   The HTTP version specified in the sampled web request, for example,
--   <tt>HTTP/1.1</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:country:HTTPRequest'</a>, <a>hTTPRequest_country</a> - The
--   two-letter country code for the country that the request originated
--   from. For a current list of country codes, see the Wikipedia entry
--   <a>ISO 3166-1 alpha-2</a>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:uri:HTTPRequest'</a>, <a>hTTPRequest_uri</a> - The part of a
--   web request that identifies the resource, for example,
--   <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:headers:HTTPRequest'</a>, <a>hTTPRequest_headers</a> - A
--   complex type that contains two values for each header in the sampled
--   web request: the name of the header and the value of the header.
--   
--   <a>$sel:method:HTTPRequest'</a>, <a>hTTPRequest_method</a> - The HTTP
--   method specified in the sampled web request. CloudFront supports the
--   following methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>, <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>,
--   <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>PUT</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:clientIP:HTTPRequest'</a>, <a>hTTPRequest_clientIP</a> - The
--   IP address that the request originated from. If the <tt>WebACL</tt> is
--   associated with a CloudFront distribution, this is the value of one of
--   the following fields in CloudFront access logs:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>c-ip</tt>, if the viewer did not use an HTTP proxy or a load
--   balancer to send the request</li>
--   <li><tt>x-forwarded-for</tt>, if the viewer did use an HTTP proxy or a
--   load balancer to send the request</li>
--   </ul>
newHTTPRequest :: HTTPRequest

-- | The HTTP version specified in the sampled web request, for example,
--   <tt>HTTP/1.1</tt>.
hTTPRequest_hTTPVersion :: Lens' HTTPRequest (Maybe Text)

-- | The two-letter country code for the country that the request
--   originated from. For a current list of country codes, see the
--   Wikipedia entry <a>ISO 3166-1 alpha-2</a>.
hTTPRequest_country :: Lens' HTTPRequest (Maybe Text)

-- | The part of a web request that identifies the resource, for example,
--   <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.
hTTPRequest_uri :: Lens' HTTPRequest (Maybe Text)

-- | A complex type that contains two values for each header in the sampled
--   web request: the name of the header and the value of the header.
hTTPRequest_headers :: Lens' HTTPRequest (Maybe [HTTPHeader])

-- | The HTTP method specified in the sampled web request. CloudFront
--   supports the following methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>, <tt>GET</tt>,
--   <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and
--   <tt>PUT</tt>.
hTTPRequest_method :: Lens' HTTPRequest (Maybe Text)

-- | The IP address that the request originated from. If the
--   <tt>WebACL</tt> is associated with a CloudFront distribution, this is
--   the value of one of the following fields in CloudFront access logs:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>c-ip</tt>, if the viewer did not use an HTTP proxy or a load
--   balancer to send the request</li>
--   <li><tt>x-forwarded-for</tt>, if the viewer did use an HTTP proxy or a
--   load balancer to send the request</li>
--   </ul>
hTTPRequest_clientIP :: Lens' HTTPRequest (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.HTTPRequest.HTTPRequest


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType
newtype IPSetDescriptorType
IPSetDescriptorType' :: Text -> IPSetDescriptorType
[fromIPSetDescriptorType] :: IPSetDescriptorType -> Text
pattern IPSetDescriptorType_IPV4 :: IPSetDescriptorType
pattern IPSetDescriptorType_IPV6 :: IPSetDescriptorType

instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptorType.IPSetDescriptorType


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Specifies the IP address type (<tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>) and the
--   IP address range (in CIDR format) that web requests originate from.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newIPSetDescriptor</a> smart constructor.
data IPSetDescriptor
IPSetDescriptor' :: IPSetDescriptorType -> Text -> IPSetDescriptor

-- | Specify <tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>.
[$sel:type':IPSetDescriptor'] :: IPSetDescriptor -> IPSetDescriptorType

-- | Specify an IPv4 address by using CIDR notation. For example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from the IP address 192.0.2.44, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from IP addresses from 192.0.2.0 to 192.0.2.255, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR notation, see the Wikipedia entry
--   <a>Classless Inter-Domain Routing</a>.
--   
--   Specify an IPv6 address by using CIDR notation. For example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from the IP address
--   1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0111, specify
--   <tt>1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0111/128</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from IP addresses 1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000
--   to 1111:0000:0000:0000:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff, specify
--   <tt>1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000/64</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:value:IPSetDescriptor'] :: IPSetDescriptor -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>IPSetDescriptor</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':IPSetDescriptor'</a>, <a>iPSetDescriptor_type</a> -
--   Specify <tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:value:IPSetDescriptor'</a>, <a>iPSetDescriptor_value</a> -
--   Specify an IPv4 address by using CIDR notation. For example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from the IP address 192.0.2.44, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from IP addresses from 192.0.2.0 to 192.0.2.255, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR notation, see the Wikipedia entry
--   <a>Classless Inter-Domain Routing</a>.
--   
--   Specify an IPv6 address by using CIDR notation. For example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from the IP address
--   1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0111, specify
--   <tt>1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0111/128</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from IP addresses 1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000
--   to 1111:0000:0000:0000:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff, specify
--   <tt>1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000/64</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
newIPSetDescriptor :: IPSetDescriptorType -> Text -> IPSetDescriptor

-- | Specify <tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>.
iPSetDescriptor_type :: Lens' IPSetDescriptor IPSetDescriptorType

-- | Specify an IPv4 address by using CIDR notation. For example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from the IP address 192.0.2.44, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.44/32</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from IP addresses from 192.0.2.0 to 192.0.2.255, specify
--   <tt>192.0.2.0/24</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   For more information about CIDR notation, see the Wikipedia entry
--   <a>Classless Inter-Domain Routing</a>.
--   
--   Specify an IPv6 address by using CIDR notation. For example:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from the IP address
--   1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0111, specify
--   <tt>1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0111/128</tt>.</li>
--   <li>To configure AWS WAF to allow, block, or count requests that
--   originated from IP addresses 1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000
--   to 1111:0000:0000:0000:ffff:ffff:ffff:ffff, specify
--   <tt>1111:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000:0000/64</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
iPSetDescriptor_value :: Lens' IPSetDescriptor Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetDescriptor.IPSetDescriptor


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Contains one or more IP addresses or blocks of IP addresses specified
--   in Classless Inter-Domain Routing (CIDR) notation. AWS WAF supports
--   IPv4 address ranges: /8 and any range between /16 through /32. AWS WAF
--   supports IPv6 address ranges: /24, /32, /48, /56, /64, and /128.
--   
--   To specify an individual IP address, you specify the four-part IP
--   address followed by a <tt>/32</tt>, for example, 192.0.2.0/32. To
--   block a range of IP addresses, you can specify /8 or any range between
--   /16 through /32 (for IPv4) or /24, /32, /48, /56, /64, or /128 (for
--   IPv6). For more information about CIDR notation, see the Wikipedia
--   entry <a>Classless Inter-Domain Routing</a>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newIPSet</a> smart constructor.
data IPSet
IPSet' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> [IPSetDescriptor] -> IPSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the IPSet. You can't change the name
--   of an <tt>IPSet</tt> after you create it.
[$sel:name:IPSet'] :: IPSet -> Maybe Text

-- | The <tt>IPSetId</tt> for an <tt>IPSet</tt>. You use <tt>IPSetId</tt>
--   to get information about an <tt>IPSet</tt> (see GetIPSet), update an
--   <tt>IPSet</tt> (see UpdateIPSet), insert an <tt>IPSet</tt> into a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and
--   delete an <tt>IPSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteIPSet).
--   
--   <tt>IPSetId</tt> is returned by CreateIPSet and by ListIPSets.
[$sel:iPSetId:IPSet'] :: IPSet -> Text

-- | The IP address type (<tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>) and the IP
--   address range (in CIDR notation) that web requests originate from. If
--   the <tt>WebACL</tt> is associated with a CloudFront distribution and
--   the viewer did not use an HTTP proxy or a load balancer to send the
--   request, this is the value of the c-ip field in the CloudFront access
--   logs.
[$sel:iPSetDescriptors:IPSet'] :: IPSet -> [IPSetDescriptor]

-- | Create a value of <a>IPSet</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:IPSet'</a>, <a>iPSet_name</a> - A friendly name or
--   description of the IPSet. You can't change the name of an
--   <tt>IPSet</tt> after you create it.
--   
--   <a>$sel:iPSetId:IPSet'</a>, <a>iPSet_iPSetId</a> - The
--   <tt>IPSetId</tt> for an <tt>IPSet</tt>. You use <tt>IPSetId</tt> to
--   get information about an <tt>IPSet</tt> (see GetIPSet), update an
--   <tt>IPSet</tt> (see UpdateIPSet), insert an <tt>IPSet</tt> into a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and
--   delete an <tt>IPSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteIPSet).
--   
--   <tt>IPSetId</tt> is returned by CreateIPSet and by ListIPSets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:iPSetDescriptors:IPSet'</a>, <a>iPSet_iPSetDescriptors</a> -
--   The IP address type (<tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>) and the IP
--   address range (in CIDR notation) that web requests originate from. If
--   the <tt>WebACL</tt> is associated with a CloudFront distribution and
--   the viewer did not use an HTTP proxy or a load balancer to send the
--   request, this is the value of the c-ip field in the CloudFront access
--   logs.
newIPSet :: Text -> IPSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the IPSet. You can't change the name
--   of an <tt>IPSet</tt> after you create it.
iPSet_name :: Lens' IPSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The <tt>IPSetId</tt> for an <tt>IPSet</tt>. You use <tt>IPSetId</tt>
--   to get information about an <tt>IPSet</tt> (see GetIPSet), update an
--   <tt>IPSet</tt> (see UpdateIPSet), insert an <tt>IPSet</tt> into a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and
--   delete an <tt>IPSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteIPSet).
--   
--   <tt>IPSetId</tt> is returned by CreateIPSet and by ListIPSets.
iPSet_iPSetId :: Lens' IPSet Text

-- | The IP address type (<tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>) and the IP
--   address range (in CIDR notation) that web requests originate from. If
--   the <tt>WebACL</tt> is associated with a CloudFront distribution and
--   the viewer did not use an HTTP proxy or a load balancer to send the
--   request, this is the value of the c-ip field in the CloudFront access
--   logs.
iPSet_iPSetDescriptors :: Lens' IPSet [IPSetDescriptor]
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSet.IPSet

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.IPSetUpdate

--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and

--   Specifies the type of update to perform to an IPSet with UpdateIPSet.

data IPSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete an IP address with UpdateIPSet.
[$sel:action:IPSetUpdate'] :: IPSetUpdate -> ChangeAction

--   <a>$sel:iPSetDescriptor:IPSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>iPSetUpdate_iPSetDescriptor</a> - The IP address type
--   (<tt>IPV4</tt> or <tt>IPV6</tt>) and the IP address range (in CIDR
--   notation) that web requests originate from.
newIPSetUpdate :: ChangeAction -> IPSetDescriptor -> IPSetUpdate

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.MatchFieldType
newtype MatchFieldType

[fromMatchFieldType] :: MatchFieldType -> Text

pattern MatchFieldType_BODY :: MatchFieldType
pattern MatchFieldType_HEADER :: MatchFieldType
pattern MatchFieldType_METHOD :: MatchFieldType
pattern MatchFieldType_QUERY_STRING :: MatchFieldType
pattern MatchFieldType_SINGLE_QUERY_ARG :: MatchFieldType
pattern MatchFieldType_URI :: MatchFieldType

instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.WAF.Types.MatchFieldType.MatchFieldType

instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.MatchFieldType.MatchFieldType
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.MatchFieldType.MatchFieldType


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Specifies where in a web request to look for <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newFieldToMatch</a> smart constructor.
data FieldToMatch
FieldToMatch' :: Maybe Text -> MatchFieldType -> FieldToMatch

-- | When the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>HEADER</tt>, enter the name of
--   the header that you want AWS WAF to search, for example,
--   <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt>. The name of the header is not
--   case sensitive.
--   
--   When the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, enter
--   the name of the parameter that you want AWS WAF to search, for
--   example, <tt>UserName</tt> or <tt>SalesRegion</tt>. The parameter name
--   is not case sensitive.
--   
--   If the value of <tt>Type</tt> is any other value, omit <tt>Data</tt>.
[$sel:data':FieldToMatch'] :: FieldToMatch -> Maybe Text

-- | The part of the web request that you want AWS WAF to search for a
--   specified string. Parts of a request that you can search include the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>HEADER</tt>: A specified request header, for example, the
--   value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt> header. If you
--   choose <tt>HEADER</tt> for the type, specify the name of the header in
--   <tt>Data</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>METHOD</tt>: The HTTP method, which indicated the type of
--   operation that the request is asking the origin to perform. Amazon
--   CloudFront supports the following methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>,
--   <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>,
--   <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>PUT</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>: A query string, which is the part of a URL
--   that appears after a <tt>?</tt> character, if any.</li>
--   <li><tt>URI</tt>: The part of a web request that identifies a
--   resource, for example, <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>BODY</tt>: The part of a request that contains any additional
--   data that you want to send to your web server as the HTTP request
--   body, such as data from a form. The request body immediately follows
--   the request headers. Note that only the first <tt>8192</tt> bytes of
--   the request body are forwarded to AWS WAF for inspection. To allow or
--   block requests based on the length of the body, you can create a size
--   constraint set. For more information, see
--   CreateSizeConstraintSet.</li>
--   <li><tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>: The parameter in the query string that
--   you will inspect, such as <i>UserName</i> or <i>SalesRegion</i>. The
--   maximum length for <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt> is 30 characters.</li>
--   <li><tt>ALL_QUERY_ARGS</tt>: Similar to <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, but
--   rather than inspecting a single parameter, AWS WAF will inspect all
--   parameters within the query for the value or regex pattern that you
--   specify in <tt>TargetString</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:type':FieldToMatch'] :: FieldToMatch -> MatchFieldType

-- | Create a value of <a>FieldToMatch</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:data':FieldToMatch'</a>, <a>fieldToMatch_data</a> - When the
--   value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>HEADER</tt>, enter the name of the
--   header that you want AWS WAF to search, for example,
--   <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt>. The name of the header is not
--   case sensitive.
--   
--   When the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, enter
--   the name of the parameter that you want AWS WAF to search, for
--   example, <tt>UserName</tt> or <tt>SalesRegion</tt>. The parameter name
--   is not case sensitive.
--   
--   If the value of <tt>Type</tt> is any other value, omit <tt>Data</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':FieldToMatch'</a>, <a>fieldToMatch_type</a> - The part
--   of the web request that you want AWS WAF to search for a specified
--   string. Parts of a request that you can search include the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>HEADER</tt>: A specified request header, for example, the
--   value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt> header. If you
--   choose <tt>HEADER</tt> for the type, specify the name of the header in
--   <tt>Data</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>METHOD</tt>: The HTTP method, which indicated the type of
--   operation that the request is asking the origin to perform. Amazon
--   CloudFront supports the following methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>,
--   <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>,
--   <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>PUT</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>: A query string, which is the part of a URL
--   that appears after a <tt>?</tt> character, if any.</li>
--   <li><tt>URI</tt>: The part of a web request that identifies a
--   resource, for example, <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>BODY</tt>: The part of a request that contains any additional
--   data that you want to send to your web server as the HTTP request
--   body, such as data from a form. The request body immediately follows
--   the request headers. Note that only the first <tt>8192</tt> bytes of
--   the request body are forwarded to AWS WAF for inspection. To allow or
--   block requests based on the length of the body, you can create a size
--   constraint set. For more information, see
--   CreateSizeConstraintSet.</li>
--   <li><tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>: The parameter in the query string that
--   you will inspect, such as <i>UserName</i> or <i>SalesRegion</i>. The
--   maximum length for <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt> is 30 characters.</li>
--   <li><tt>ALL_QUERY_ARGS</tt>: Similar to <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, but
--   rather than inspecting a single parameter, AWS WAF will inspect all
--   parameters within the query for the value or regex pattern that you
--   specify in <tt>TargetString</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
newFieldToMatch :: MatchFieldType -> FieldToMatch

-- | When the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>HEADER</tt>, enter the name of
--   the header that you want AWS WAF to search, for example,
--   <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt>. The name of the header is not
--   case sensitive.
--   
--   When the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, enter
--   the name of the parameter that you want AWS WAF to search, for
--   example, <tt>UserName</tt> or <tt>SalesRegion</tt>. The parameter name
--   is not case sensitive.
--   
--   If the value of <tt>Type</tt> is any other value, omit <tt>Data</tt>.
fieldToMatch_data :: Lens' FieldToMatch (Maybe Text)

-- | The part of the web request that you want AWS WAF to search for a
--   specified string. Parts of a request that you can search include the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>HEADER</tt>: A specified request header, for example, the
--   value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt> header. If you
--   choose <tt>HEADER</tt> for the type, specify the name of the header in
--   <tt>Data</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>METHOD</tt>: The HTTP method, which indicated the type of
--   operation that the request is asking the origin to perform. Amazon
--   CloudFront supports the following methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>,
--   <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>, <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>,
--   <tt>POST</tt>, and <tt>PUT</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>: A query string, which is the part of a URL
--   that appears after a <tt>?</tt> character, if any.</li>
--   <li><tt>URI</tt>: The part of a web request that identifies a
--   resource, for example, <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>BODY</tt>: The part of a request that contains any additional
--   data that you want to send to your web server as the HTTP request
--   body, such as data from a form. The request body immediately follows
--   the request headers. Note that only the first <tt>8192</tt> bytes of
--   the request body are forwarded to AWS WAF for inspection. To allow or
--   block requests based on the length of the body, you can create a size
--   constraint set. For more information, see
--   CreateSizeConstraintSet.</li>
--   <li><tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>: The parameter in the query string that
--   you will inspect, such as <i>UserName</i> or <i>SalesRegion</i>. The
--   maximum length for <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt> is 30 characters.</li>
--   <li><tt>ALL_QUERY_ARGS</tt>: Similar to <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, but
--   rather than inspecting a single parameter, AWS WAF will inspect all
--   parameters within the query for the value or regex pattern that you
--   specify in <tt>TargetString</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
fieldToMatch_type :: Lens' FieldToMatch MatchFieldType
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.FieldToMatch.FieldToMatch


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose, <tt>RedactedFields</tt> information,
--   and the web ACL Amazon Resource Name (ARN).
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newLoggingConfiguration</a> smart constructor.
data LoggingConfiguration
LoggingConfiguration' :: Maybe [FieldToMatch] -> Text -> NonEmpty Text -> LoggingConfiguration

-- | The parts of the request that you want redacted from the logs. For
--   example, if you redact the cookie field, the cookie field in the
--   firehose will be <tt>xxx</tt>.
[$sel:redactedFields:LoggingConfiguration'] :: LoggingConfiguration -> Maybe [FieldToMatch]

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the web ACL that you want to
--   associate with <tt>LogDestinationConfigs</tt>.
[$sel:resourceArn:LoggingConfiguration'] :: LoggingConfiguration -> Text

-- | An array of Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose ARNs.
[$sel:logDestinationConfigs:LoggingConfiguration'] :: LoggingConfiguration -> NonEmpty Text

-- | Create a value of <a>LoggingConfiguration</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:redactedFields:LoggingConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>loggingConfiguration_redactedFields</a> - The parts of the request
--   that you want redacted from the logs. For example, if you redact the
--   cookie field, the cookie field in the firehose will be <tt>xxx</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:resourceArn:LoggingConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>loggingConfiguration_resourceArn</a> - The Amazon Resource Name
--   (ARN) of the web ACL that you want to associate with
--   <tt>LogDestinationConfigs</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:logDestinationConfigs:LoggingConfiguration'</a>,
--   <a>loggingConfiguration_logDestinationConfigs</a> - An array of Amazon
--   Kinesis Data Firehose ARNs.
newLoggingConfiguration :: Text -> NonEmpty Text -> LoggingConfiguration

-- | The parts of the request that you want redacted from the logs. For
--   example, if you redact the cookie field, the cookie field in the
--   firehose will be <tt>xxx</tt>.
loggingConfiguration_redactedFields :: Lens' LoggingConfiguration (Maybe [FieldToMatch])

-- | The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the web ACL that you want to
--   associate with <tt>LogDestinationConfigs</tt>.
loggingConfiguration_resourceArn :: Lens' LoggingConfiguration Text

-- | An array of Amazon Kinesis Data Firehose ARNs.
loggingConfiguration_logDestinationConfigs :: Lens' LoggingConfiguration (NonEmpty Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.LoggingConfiguration.LoggingConfiguration

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Specifies the ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet,
--   RegexMatchSet, GeoMatchSet, and SizeConstraintSet objects that you
--   want to add to a <tt>Rule</tt> and, for each object, indicates whether
--   you want to negate the settings, for example, requests that do NOT
--   originate from the IP address 192.0.2.44.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newPredicate</a> smart constructor.
data Predicate
Predicate' :: Bool -> PredicateType -> Text -> Predicate

-- | Set <tt>Negated</tt> to <tt>False</tt> if you want AWS WAF to allow,
--   block, or count requests based on the settings in the specified
--   ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, RegexMatchSet,
--   GeoMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet. For example, if an <tt>IPSet</tt>
--   includes the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, AWS WAF will allow or
--   block requests based on that IP address.
--   
--   Set <tt>Negated</tt> to <tt>True</tt> if you want AWS WAF to allow or
--   block a request based on the negation of the settings in the
--   ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, RegexMatchSet,
--   GeoMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet. For example, if an <tt>IPSet</tt>
--   includes the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, AWS WAF will allow,
--   block, or count requests based on all IP addresses <i>except</i>
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>.
[$sel:negated:Predicate'] :: Predicate -> Bool

-- | The type of predicate in a <tt>Rule</tt>, such as <tt>ByteMatch</tt>
--   or <tt>IPSet</tt>.
[$sel:type':Predicate'] :: Predicate -> PredicateType

-- | A unique identifier for a predicate in a <tt>Rule</tt>, such as
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> or <tt>IPSetId</tt>. The ID is returned by the
--   corresponding <tt>Create</tt> or <tt>List</tt> command.
[$sel:dataId:Predicate'] :: Predicate -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>Predicate</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:negated:Predicate'</a>, <a>predicate_negated</a> - Set
--   <tt>Negated</tt> to <tt>False</tt> if you want AWS WAF to allow,
--   block, or count requests based on the settings in the specified
--   ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, RegexMatchSet,
--   GeoMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet. For example, if an <tt>IPSet</tt>
--   includes the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, AWS WAF will allow or
--   block requests based on that IP address.
--   
--   Set <tt>Negated</tt> to <tt>True</tt> if you want AWS WAF to allow or
--   block a request based on the negation of the settings in the
--   ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, RegexMatchSet,
--   GeoMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet. For example, if an <tt>IPSet</tt>
--   includes the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, AWS WAF will allow,
--   block, or count requests based on all IP addresses <i>except</i>
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':Predicate'</a>, <a>predicate_type</a> - The type of
--   predicate in a <tt>Rule</tt>, such as <tt>ByteMatch</tt> or
--   <tt>IPSet</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:dataId:Predicate'</a>, <a>predicate_dataId</a> - A unique
--   identifier for a predicate in a <tt>Rule</tt>, such as
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> or <tt>IPSetId</tt>. The ID is returned by the
--   corresponding <tt>Create</tt> or <tt>List</tt> command.
newPredicate :: Bool -> PredicateType -> Text -> Predicate

-- | Set <tt>Negated</tt> to <tt>False</tt> if you want AWS WAF to allow,
--   block, or count requests based on the settings in the specified
--   ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, RegexMatchSet,
--   GeoMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet. For example, if an <tt>IPSet</tt>
--   includes the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, AWS WAF will allow or
--   block requests based on that IP address.
--   
--   Set <tt>Negated</tt> to <tt>True</tt> if you want AWS WAF to allow or
--   block a request based on the negation of the settings in the
--   ByteMatchSet, IPSet, SqlInjectionMatchSet, XssMatchSet, RegexMatchSet,
--   GeoMatchSet, or SizeConstraintSet. For example, if an <tt>IPSet</tt>
--   includes the IP address <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>, AWS WAF will allow,
--   block, or count requests based on all IP addresses <i>except</i>
--   <tt>192.0.2.44</tt>.
predicate_negated :: Lens' Predicate Bool

-- | The type of predicate in a <tt>Rule</tt>, such as <tt>ByteMatch</tt>
--   or <tt>IPSet</tt>.
predicate_type :: Lens' Predicate PredicateType

-- | A unique identifier for a predicate in a <tt>Rule</tt>, such as
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> or <tt>IPSetId</tt>. The ID is returned by the
--   corresponding <tt>Create</tt> or <tt>List</tt> command.
predicate_dataId :: Lens' Predicate Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.Predicate.Predicate


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey
newtype RateKey
RateKey' :: Text -> RateKey
[fromRateKey] :: RateKey -> Text
pattern RateKey_IP :: RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.ToXML Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.XML.FromXML Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSONKey Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSONKey Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.Query.ToQuery Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.Headers.ToHeader Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.Log.ToLog Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.ByteString.ToByteString Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.ToText Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Amazonka.Data.Text.FromText Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance GHC.Classes.Ord Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateKey.RateKey


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   A <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> is identical to a regular Rule, with one
--   addition: a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> counts the number of requests that
--   arrive from a specified IP address every five minutes. For example,
--   based on recent requests that you've seen from an attacker, you might
--   create a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> that includes the following
--   conditions:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The requests come from 192.0.2.44.</li>
--   <li>They contain the value <tt>BadBot</tt> in the <tt>User-Agent</tt>
--   header.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   In the rule, you also define the rate limit as 1,000.
--   
--   Requests that meet both of these conditions and exceed 1,000 requests
--   every five minutes trigger the rule's action (block or count), which
--   is defined in the web ACL.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRateBasedRule</a> smart constructor.
data RateBasedRule
RateBasedRule' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe Text -> Text -> [Predicate] -> RateKey -> Natural -> RateBasedRule

-- | A friendly name or description for the metrics for a
--   <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. The name can contain only alphanumeric
--   characters (A-Z, a-z, 0-9), with maximum length 128 and minimum length
--   one. It can't contain whitespace or metric names reserved for AWS WAF,
--   including "All" and "Default_Action." You can't change the name of the
--   metric after you create the <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
[$sel:metricName:RateBasedRule'] :: RateBasedRule -> Maybe Text

-- | A friendly name or description for a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. You can't
--   change the name of a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> after you create it.
[$sel:name:RateBasedRule'] :: RateBasedRule -> Maybe Text

-- | A unique identifier for a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RuleId</tt> to get more information about a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>
--   (see GetRateBasedRule), update a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> (see
--   UpdateRateBasedRule), insert a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> into a
--   <tt>WebACL</tt> or delete one from a <tt>WebACL</tt> (see
--   UpdateWebACL), or delete a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> from AWS WAF (see
--   DeleteRateBasedRule).
[$sel:ruleId:RateBasedRule'] :: RateBasedRule -> Text

-- | The <tt>Predicates</tt> object contains one <tt>Predicate</tt> element
--   for each ByteMatchSet, IPSet, or SqlInjectionMatchSet object that you
--   want to include in a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
[$sel:matchPredicates:RateBasedRule'] :: RateBasedRule -> [Predicate]

-- | The field that AWS WAF uses to determine if requests are likely
--   arriving from single source and thus subject to rate monitoring. The
--   only valid value for <tt>RateKey</tt> is <tt>IP</tt>. <tt>IP</tt>
--   indicates that requests arriving from the same IP address are subject
--   to the <tt>RateLimit</tt> that is specified in the
--   <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
[$sel:rateKey:RateBasedRule'] :: RateBasedRule -> RateKey

-- | The maximum number of requests, which have an identical value in the
--   field specified by the <tt>RateKey</tt>, allowed in a five-minute
--   period. If the number of requests exceeds the <tt>RateLimit</tt> and
--   the other predicates specified in the rule are also met, AWS WAF
--   triggers the action that is specified for this rule.
[$sel:rateLimit:RateBasedRule'] :: RateBasedRule -> Natural

-- | Create a value of <a>RateBasedRule</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:metricName:RateBasedRule'</a>, <a>rateBasedRule_metricName</a>
--   - A friendly name or description for the metrics for a
--   <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. The name can contain only alphanumeric
--   characters (A-Z, a-z, 0-9), with maximum length 128 and minimum length
--   one. It can't contain whitespace or metric names reserved for AWS WAF,
--   including "All" and "Default_Action." You can't change the name of the
--   metric after you create the <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RateBasedRule'</a>, <a>rateBasedRule_name</a> - A
--   friendly name or description for a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. You can't
--   change the name of a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> after you create it.
--   
--   <a>$sel:ruleId:RateBasedRule'</a>, <a>rateBasedRule_ruleId</a> - A
--   unique identifier for a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RuleId</tt> to get more information about a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>
--   (see GetRateBasedRule), update a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> (see
--   UpdateRateBasedRule), insert a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> into a
--   <tt>WebACL</tt> or delete one from a <tt>WebACL</tt> (see
--   UpdateWebACL), or delete a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> from AWS WAF (see
--   DeleteRateBasedRule).
--   
--   <a>$sel:matchPredicates:RateBasedRule'</a>,
--   <a>rateBasedRule_matchPredicates</a> - The <tt>Predicates</tt> object
--   contains one <tt>Predicate</tt> element for each ByteMatchSet, IPSet,
--   or SqlInjectionMatchSet object that you want to include in a
--   <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rateKey:RateBasedRule'</a>, <a>rateBasedRule_rateKey</a> - The
--   field that AWS WAF uses to determine if requests are likely arriving
--   from single source and thus subject to rate monitoring. The only valid
--   value for <tt>RateKey</tt> is <tt>IP</tt>. <tt>IP</tt> indicates that
--   requests arriving from the same IP address are subject to the
--   <tt>RateLimit</tt> that is specified in the <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:rateLimit:RateBasedRule'</a>, <a>rateBasedRule_rateLimit</a> -
--   The maximum number of requests, which have an identical value in the
--   field specified by the <tt>RateKey</tt>, allowed in a five-minute
--   period. If the number of requests exceeds the <tt>RateLimit</tt> and
--   the other predicates specified in the rule are also met, AWS WAF
--   triggers the action that is specified for this rule.
newRateBasedRule :: Text -> RateKey -> Natural -> RateBasedRule

-- | A friendly name or description for the metrics for a
--   <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. The name can contain only alphanumeric
--   characters (A-Z, a-z, 0-9), with maximum length 128 and minimum length
--   one. It can't contain whitespace or metric names reserved for AWS WAF,
--   including "All" and "Default_Action." You can't change the name of the
--   metric after you create the <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
rateBasedRule_metricName :: Lens' RateBasedRule (Maybe Text)

-- | A friendly name or description for a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. You can't
--   change the name of a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> after you create it.
rateBasedRule_name :: Lens' RateBasedRule (Maybe Text)

-- | A unique identifier for a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RuleId</tt> to get more information about a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>
--   (see GetRateBasedRule), update a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> (see
--   UpdateRateBasedRule), insert a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> into a
--   <tt>WebACL</tt> or delete one from a <tt>WebACL</tt> (see
--   UpdateWebACL), or delete a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt> from AWS WAF (see
--   DeleteRateBasedRule).
rateBasedRule_ruleId :: Lens' RateBasedRule Text

-- | The <tt>Predicates</tt> object contains one <tt>Predicate</tt> element
--   for each ByteMatchSet, IPSet, or SqlInjectionMatchSet object that you
--   want to include in a <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
rateBasedRule_matchPredicates :: Lens' RateBasedRule [Predicate]

-- | The field that AWS WAF uses to determine if requests are likely
--   arriving from single source and thus subject to rate monitoring. The
--   only valid value for <tt>RateKey</tt> is <tt>IP</tt>. <tt>IP</tt>
--   indicates that requests arriving from the same IP address are subject
--   to the <tt>RateLimit</tt> that is specified in the
--   <tt>RateBasedRule</tt>.
rateBasedRule_rateKey :: Lens' RateBasedRule RateKey

-- | The maximum number of requests, which have an identical value in the
--   field specified by the <tt>RateKey</tt>, allowed in a five-minute
--   period. If the number of requests exceeds the <tt>RateLimit</tt> and
--   the other predicates specified in the rule are also met, AWS WAF
--   triggers the action that is specified for this rule.
rateBasedRule_rateLimit :: Lens' RateBasedRule Natural
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.RateBasedRule.RateBasedRule


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetSummary

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   Returned by ListRegexMatchSets. Each <tt>RegexMatchSetSummary</tt>
--   object includes the <tt>Name</tt> and <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> for one
--   RegexMatchSet.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegexMatchSetSummary</a> smart constructor.

--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> from AWS WAF.

--   ListRegexMatchSets.

--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexMatchSet and by

--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RegexMatchSetSummary'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchSetSummary_name</a> - A friendly name or description of
--   the RegexMatchSet. You can't change <tt>Name</tt> after you create a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
newRegexMatchSetSummary :: Text -> Text -> RegexMatchSetSummary

--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>, update a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>, remove a

--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> from AWS WAF.
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexMatchSet and by
--   ListRegexMatchSets.
regexMatchSetSummary_regexMatchSetId :: Lens' RegexMatchSetSummary Text

--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> specifies the regular expression (regex)
--   pattern that you want AWS WAF to search for, such as
--   <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>. You can then configure AWS WAF to reject those
--   requests.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegexPatternSet</a> smart constructor.
data RegexPatternSet
RegexPatternSet' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> [Text] -> RegexPatternSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the RegexPatternSet. You can't
--   change <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>.
[$sel:name:RegexPatternSet'] :: RegexPatternSet -> Maybe Text

-- | The identifier for the <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>, update a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>, remove a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>, and delete a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from AWS WAF.
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexPatternSet and by
--   ListRegexPatternSets.
[$sel:regexPatternSetId:RegexPatternSet'] :: RegexPatternSet -> Text

-- | Specifies the regular expression (regex) patterns that you want AWS
--   WAF to search for, such as <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>.
[$sel:regexPatternStrings:RegexPatternSet'] :: RegexPatternSet -> [Text]

-- | Create a value of <a>RegexPatternSet</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RegexPatternSet'</a>, <a>regexPatternSet_name</a> - A
--   friendly name or description of the RegexPatternSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexPatternSetId:RegexPatternSet'</a>,
--   <a>regexPatternSet_regexPatternSetId</a> - The identifier for the
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>. You use <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> to get
--   information about a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>, update a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>, remove a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>, and delete a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from AWS
--   WAF.
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexPatternSet and by
--   ListRegexPatternSets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexPatternStrings:RegexPatternSet'</a>,
--   <a>regexPatternSet_regexPatternStrings</a> - Specifies the regular
--   expression (regex) patterns that you want AWS WAF to search for, such
--   as <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>.
newRegexPatternSet :: Text -> RegexPatternSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the RegexPatternSet. You can't
--   change <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>.
regexPatternSet_name :: Lens' RegexPatternSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The identifier for the <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>, update a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>, remove a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>, and delete a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from AWS WAF.
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexPatternSet and by
--   ListRegexPatternSets.
regexPatternSet_regexPatternSetId :: Lens' RegexPatternSet Text

-- | Specifies the regular expression (regex) patterns that you want AWS
--   WAF to search for, such as <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>.
regexPatternSet_regexPatternStrings :: Lens' RegexPatternSet [Text]
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSet.RegexPatternSet

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexPatternSetUpdate

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   In an UpdateRegexPatternSet request, <tt>RegexPatternSetUpdate</tt>
--   specifies whether to insert or delete a <tt>RegexPatternString</tt>
--   and includes the settings for the <tt>RegexPatternString</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegexPatternSetUpdate</a> smart constructor.
data RegexPatternSetUpdate
RegexPatternSetUpdate' :: ChangeAction -> Text -> RegexPatternSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a <tt>RegexPatternString</tt>.
[$sel:action:RegexPatternSetUpdate'] :: RegexPatternSetUpdate -> ChangeAction

-- | Specifies the regular expression (regex) pattern that you want AWS WAF
--   to search for, such as <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>.
[$sel:regexPatternString:RegexPatternSetUpdate'] :: RegexPatternSetUpdate -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RegexPatternSetUpdate</a> with all optional
--   fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:action:RegexPatternSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>regexPatternSetUpdate_action</a> - Specifies whether to insert or
--   delete a <tt>RegexPatternString</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexPatternString:RegexPatternSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>regexPatternSetUpdate_regexPatternString</a> - Specifies the
--   regular expression (regex) pattern that you want AWS WAF to search
--   for, such as <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>.
newRegexPatternSetUpdate :: ChangeAction -> Text -> RegexPatternSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a <tt>RegexPatternString</tt>.
regexPatternSetUpdate_action :: Lens' RegexPatternSetUpdate ChangeAction

-- | Specifies the regular expression (regex) pattern that you want AWS WAF
--   to search for, such as <tt>B[a@]dB[o0]t</tt>.
regexPatternSetUpdate_regexPatternString :: Lens' RegexPatternSetUpdate Text
