module Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   A complex type that contains <tt>SizeConstraint</tt> objects, which
--   specify the parts of web requests that you want AWS WAF to inspect the
--   size of. If a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> contains more than one
--   <tt>SizeConstraint</tt> object, a request only needs to match one
--   constraint to be considered a match.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newSizeConstraintSet</a> smart constructor.
data SizeConstraintSet
SizeConstraintSet' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> [SizeConstraint] -> SizeConstraintSet

-- | The name, if any, of the <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt>.
[$sel:name:SizeConstraintSet'] :: SizeConstraintSet -> Maybe Text

-- | A unique identifier for a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> (see GetSizeConstraintSet), update a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> (see UpdateSizeConstraintSet), insert a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteSizeConstraintSet).
--   
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSetId</tt> is returned by CreateSizeConstraintSet
--   and by ListSizeConstraintSets.
[$sel:sizeConstraintSetId:SizeConstraintSet'] :: SizeConstraintSet -> Text

-- | Specifies the parts of web requests that you want to inspect the size
--   of.
[$sel:sizeConstraints:SizeConstraintSet'] :: SizeConstraintSet -> [SizeConstraint]

-- | Create a value of <a>SizeConstraintSet</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:SizeConstraintSet'</a>, <a>sizeConstraintSet_name</a> -
--   The name, if any, of the <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sizeConstraintSetId:SizeConstraintSet'</a>,
--   <a>sizeConstraintSet_sizeConstraintSetId</a> - A unique identifier for
--   a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt>. You use <tt>SizeConstraintSetId</tt> to
--   get information about a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> (see
--   GetSizeConstraintSet), update a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> (see
--   UpdateSizeConstraintSet), insert a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> into a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and
--   delete a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see
--   DeleteSizeConstraintSet).
--   
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSetId</tt> is returned by CreateSizeConstraintSet
--   and by ListSizeConstraintSets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:sizeConstraints:SizeConstraintSet'</a>,
--   <a>sizeConstraintSet_sizeConstraints</a> - Specifies the parts of web
--   requests that you want to inspect the size of.
newSizeConstraintSet :: Text -> SizeConstraintSet

-- | The name, if any, of the <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt>.
sizeConstraintSet_name :: Lens' SizeConstraintSet (Maybe Text)

-- | A unique identifier for a <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> (see GetSizeConstraintSet), update a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> (see UpdateSizeConstraintSet), insert a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteSizeConstraintSet).
--   
--   <tt>SizeConstraintSetId</tt> is returned by CreateSizeConstraintSet
--   and by ListSizeConstraintSets.
sizeConstraintSet_sizeConstraintSetId :: Lens' SizeConstraintSet Text

-- | Specifies the parts of web requests that you want to inspect the size
--   of.
sizeConstraintSet_sizeConstraints :: Lens' SizeConstraintSet [SizeConstraint]
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.SizeConstraintSet.SizeConstraintSet


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The regular expression pattern that you want AWS WAF to search for in
--   web requests, the location in requests that you want AWS WAF to
--   search, and other settings. Each <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> object
--   contains:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to inspect, such
--   as a query string or the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header.</li>
--   <li>The identifier of the pattern (a regular expression) that you want
--   AWS WAF to look for. For more information, see RegexPatternSet.</li>
--   <li>Whether to perform any conversions on the request, such as
--   converting it to lowercase, before inspecting it for the specified
--   string.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegexMatchTuple</a> smart constructor.
data RegexMatchTuple
RegexMatchTuple' :: FieldToMatch -> TextTransformation -> Text -> RegexMatchTuple

-- | Specifies where in a web request to look for the
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>.
[$sel:fieldToMatch:RegexMatchTuple'] :: RegexMatchTuple -> FieldToMatch

-- | Text transformations eliminate some of the unusual formatting that
--   attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF. If you
--   specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> before inspecting a request for a match.
--   
--   You can only specify a single type of TextTransformation.
--   
--   <b>CMD_LINE</b>
--   
--   When you're concerned that attackers are injecting an operating system
--   commandline command and using unusual formatting to disguise some or
--   all of the command, use this option to perform the following
--   transformations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Delete the following characters: \ " ' ^</li>
--   <li>Delete spaces before the following characters: / (</li>
--   <li>Replace the following characters with a space: , ;</li>
--   <li>Replace multiple spaces with one space</li>
--   <li>Convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace the following characters with a space
--   character (decimal 32):
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>\f, formfeed, decimal 12</li>
--   <li>\t, tab, decimal 9</li>
--   <li>\n, newline, decimal 10</li>
--   <li>\r, carriage return, decimal 13</li>
--   <li>\v, vertical tab, decimal 11</li>
--   <li>non-breaking space, decimal 160</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</tt> also replaces multiple spaces with one
--   space.
--   
--   <b>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace HTML-encoded characters with unencoded
--   characters. <tt>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</tt> performs the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)quot;</tt> with <tt>"</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)nbsp;</tt> with a non-breaking space,
--   decimal 160</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)lt;</tt> with a "less than" symbol</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)gt;</tt> with <tt>&gt;</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in hexadecimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#xhhhh;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in decimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#nnnn;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>LOWERCASE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z).
--   
--   <b>URL_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to decode a URL-encoded value.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>
--   
--   Specify <tt>NONE</tt> if you don't want to perform any text
--   transformations.
[$sel:textTransformation:RegexMatchTuple'] :: RegexMatchTuple -> TextTransformation

-- | The <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> for a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> (see GetRegexPatternSet), update a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexPatternSet), insert a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> into a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> or delete one
--   from a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexMatchSet), and delete an
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteRegexPatternSet).
--   
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexPatternSet and by
--   ListRegexPatternSets.
[$sel:regexPatternSetId:RegexMatchTuple'] :: RegexMatchTuple -> Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RegexMatchTuple</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fieldToMatch:RegexMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchTuple_fieldToMatch</a> - Specifies where in a web request
--   to look for the <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:textTransformation:RegexMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchTuple_textTransformation</a> - Text transformations
--   eliminate some of the unusual formatting that attackers use in web
--   requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF. If you specify a
--   transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> before inspecting a request for a match.
--   
--   You can only specify a single type of TextTransformation.
--   
--   <b>CMD_LINE</b>
--   
--   When you're concerned that attackers are injecting an operating system
--   commandline command and using unusual formatting to disguise some or
--   all of the command, use this option to perform the following
--   transformations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Delete the following characters: \ " ' ^</li>
--   <li>Delete spaces before the following characters: / (</li>
--   <li>Replace the following characters with a space: , ;</li>
--   <li>Replace multiple spaces with one space</li>
--   <li>Convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace the following characters with a space
--   character (decimal 32):
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>\f, formfeed, decimal 12</li>
--   <li>\t, tab, decimal 9</li>
--   <li>\n, newline, decimal 10</li>
--   <li>\r, carriage return, decimal 13</li>
--   <li>\v, vertical tab, decimal 11</li>
--   <li>non-breaking space, decimal 160</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</tt> also replaces multiple spaces with one
--   space.
--   
--   <b>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace HTML-encoded characters with unencoded
--   characters. <tt>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</tt> performs the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)quot;</tt> with <tt>"</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)nbsp;</tt> with a non-breaking space,
--   decimal 160</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)lt;</tt> with a "less than" symbol</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)gt;</tt> with <tt>&gt;</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in hexadecimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#xhhhh;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in decimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#nnnn;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>LOWERCASE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z).
--   
--   <b>URL_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to decode a URL-encoded value.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>
--   
--   Specify <tt>NONE</tt> if you don't want to perform any text
--   transformations.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexPatternSetId:RegexMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchTuple_regexPatternSetId</a> - The
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> for a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> (see GetRegexPatternSet), update a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexPatternSet), insert a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> into a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> or delete one
--   from a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexMatchSet), and delete an
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteRegexPatternSet).
--   
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexPatternSet and by
--   ListRegexPatternSets.
newRegexMatchTuple :: FieldToMatch -> TextTransformation -> Text -> RegexMatchTuple

-- | Specifies where in a web request to look for the
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>.
regexMatchTuple_fieldToMatch :: Lens' RegexMatchTuple FieldToMatch

-- | Text transformations eliminate some of the unusual formatting that
--   attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF. If you
--   specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> before inspecting a request for a match.
--   
--   You can only specify a single type of TextTransformation.
--   
--   <b>CMD_LINE</b>
--   
--   When you're concerned that attackers are injecting an operating system
--   commandline command and using unusual formatting to disguise some or
--   all of the command, use this option to perform the following
--   transformations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Delete the following characters: \ " ' ^</li>
--   <li>Delete spaces before the following characters: / (</li>
--   <li>Replace the following characters with a space: , ;</li>
--   <li>Replace multiple spaces with one space</li>
--   <li>Convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace the following characters with a space
--   character (decimal 32):
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>\f, formfeed, decimal 12</li>
--   <li>\t, tab, decimal 9</li>
--   <li>\n, newline, decimal 10</li>
--   <li>\r, carriage return, decimal 13</li>
--   <li>\v, vertical tab, decimal 11</li>
--   <li>non-breaking space, decimal 160</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</tt> also replaces multiple spaces with one
--   space.
--   
--   <b>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace HTML-encoded characters with unencoded
--   characters. <tt>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</tt> performs the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)quot;</tt> with <tt>"</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)nbsp;</tt> with a non-breaking space,
--   decimal 160</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)lt;</tt> with a "less than" symbol</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)gt;</tt> with <tt>&gt;</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in hexadecimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#xhhhh;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in decimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#nnnn;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>LOWERCASE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z).
--   
--   <b>URL_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to decode a URL-encoded value.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>
--   
--   Specify <tt>NONE</tt> if you don't want to perform any text
--   transformations.
regexMatchTuple_textTransformation :: Lens' RegexMatchTuple TextTransformation

-- | The <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> for a <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> (see GetRegexPatternSet), update a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexPatternSet), insert a
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> into a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> or delete one
--   from a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexMatchSet), and delete an
--   <tt>RegexPatternSet</tt> from AWS WAF (see DeleteRegexPatternSet).
--   
--   <tt>RegexPatternSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexPatternSet and by
--   ListRegexPatternSets.
regexMatchTuple_regexPatternSetId :: Lens' RegexMatchTuple Text
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchTuple.RegexMatchTuple


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   In an UpdateRegexMatchSet request, <tt>RegexMatchSetUpdate</tt>
--   specifies whether to insert or delete a RegexMatchTuple and includes
--   the settings for the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegexMatchSetUpdate</a> smart constructor.
data RegexMatchSetUpdate
RegexMatchSetUpdate' :: ChangeAction -> RegexMatchTuple -> RegexMatchSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a RegexMatchTuple.
[$sel:action:RegexMatchSetUpdate'] :: RegexMatchSetUpdate -> ChangeAction

-- | Information about the part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to
--   inspect and the identifier of the regular expression (regex) pattern
--   that you want AWS WAF to search for. If you specify <tt>DELETE</tt>
--   for the value of <tt>Action</tt>, the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> values
--   must exactly match the values in the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> that you
--   want to delete from the <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
[$sel:regexMatchTuple:RegexMatchSetUpdate'] :: RegexMatchSetUpdate -> RegexMatchTuple

-- | Create a value of <a>RegexMatchSetUpdate</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:action:RegexMatchSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchSetUpdate_action</a> - Specifies whether to insert or
--   delete a RegexMatchTuple.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexMatchTuple:RegexMatchSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchSetUpdate_regexMatchTuple</a> - Information about the
--   part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to inspect and the
--   identifier of the regular expression (regex) pattern that you want AWS
--   WAF to search for. If you specify <tt>DELETE</tt> for the value of
--   <tt>Action</tt>, the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> values must exactly
--   match the values in the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> that you want to
--   delete from the <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
newRegexMatchSetUpdate :: ChangeAction -> RegexMatchTuple -> RegexMatchSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a RegexMatchTuple.
regexMatchSetUpdate_action :: Lens' RegexMatchSetUpdate ChangeAction

-- | Information about the part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to
--   inspect and the identifier of the regular expression (regex) pattern
--   that you want AWS WAF to search for. If you specify <tt>DELETE</tt>
--   for the value of <tt>Action</tt>, the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> values
--   must exactly match the values in the <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> that you
--   want to delete from the <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
regexMatchSetUpdate_regexMatchTuple :: Lens' RegexMatchSetUpdate RegexMatchTuple
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSetUpdate.RegexMatchSetUpdate


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   In a GetRegexMatchSet request, <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> is a complex
--   type that contains the <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> and <tt>Name</tt> of a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>, and the values that you specified when you
--   updated the <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
--   
--   The values are contained in a <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> object, which
--   specify the parts of web requests that you want AWS WAF to inspect and
--   the values that you want AWS WAF to search for. If a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> contains more than one <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt>
--   object, a request needs to match the settings in only one
--   <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> to be considered a match.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newRegexMatchSet</a> smart constructor.
data RegexMatchSet
RegexMatchSet' :: Maybe Text -> Maybe [RegexMatchTuple] -> Maybe Text -> RegexMatchSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the RegexMatchSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
[$sel:name:RegexMatchSet'] :: RegexMatchSet -> Maybe Text

-- | Contains an array of RegexMatchTuple objects. Each
--   <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> object contains:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to inspect, such
--   as a query string or the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header.</li>
--   <li>The identifier of the pattern (a regular expression) that you want
--   AWS WAF to look for. For more information, see RegexPatternSet.</li>
--   <li>Whether to perform any conversions on the request, such as
--   converting it to lowercase, before inspecting it for the specified
--   string.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:regexMatchTuples:RegexMatchSet'] :: RegexMatchSet -> Maybe [RegexMatchTuple]

-- | The <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> for a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see GetRegexMatchSet), update a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>
--   from AWS WAF (see DeleteRegexMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexMatchSet and by
--   ListRegexMatchSets.
[$sel:regexMatchSetId:RegexMatchSet'] :: RegexMatchSet -> Maybe Text

-- | Create a value of <a>RegexMatchSet</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:RegexMatchSet'</a>, <a>regexMatchSet_name</a> - A
--   friendly name or description of the RegexMatchSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexMatchTuples:RegexMatchSet'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchSet_regexMatchTuples</a> - Contains an array of
--   RegexMatchTuple objects. Each <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> object
--   contains:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to inspect, such
--   as a query string or the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header.</li>
--   <li>The identifier of the pattern (a regular expression) that you want
--   AWS WAF to look for. For more information, see RegexPatternSet.</li>
--   <li>Whether to perform any conversions on the request, such as
--   converting it to lowercase, before inspecting it for the specified
--   string.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <a>$sel:regexMatchSetId:RegexMatchSet'</a>,
--   <a>regexMatchSet_regexMatchSetId</a> - The <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt>
--   for a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>. You use <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> to get
--   information about a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see GetRegexMatchSet),
--   update a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>
--   from AWS WAF (see DeleteRegexMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexMatchSet and by
--   ListRegexMatchSets.
newRegexMatchSet :: RegexMatchSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the RegexMatchSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>.
regexMatchSet_name :: Lens' RegexMatchSet (Maybe Text)

-- | Contains an array of RegexMatchTuple objects. Each
--   <tt>RegexMatchTuple</tt> object contains:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>The part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to inspect, such
--   as a query string or the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header.</li>
--   <li>The identifier of the pattern (a regular expression) that you want
--   AWS WAF to look for. For more information, see RegexPatternSet.</li>
--   <li>Whether to perform any conversions on the request, such as
--   converting it to lowercase, before inspecting it for the specified
--   string.</li>
--   </ul>
regexMatchSet_regexMatchTuples :: Lens' RegexMatchSet (Maybe [RegexMatchTuple])

-- | The <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> for a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see GetRegexMatchSet), update a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateRegexMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>RegexMatchSet</tt>
--   from AWS WAF (see DeleteRegexMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>RegexMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateRegexMatchSet and by
--   ListRegexMatchSets.
regexMatchSet_regexMatchSetId :: Lens' RegexMatchSet (Maybe Text)
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.RegexMatchSet.RegexMatchSet


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The bytes (typically a string that corresponds with ASCII characters)
--   that you want AWS WAF to search for in web requests, the location in
--   requests that you want AWS WAF to search, and other settings.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newByteMatchTuple</a> smart constructor.
data ByteMatchTuple
ByteMatchTuple' :: FieldToMatch -> Base64 -> TextTransformation -> PositionalConstraint -> ByteMatchTuple

-- | The part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to search, such as a
--   specified header or a query string. For more information, see
--   FieldToMatch.
[$sel:fieldToMatch:ByteMatchTuple'] :: ByteMatchTuple -> FieldToMatch

-- | The value that you want AWS WAF to search for. AWS WAF searches for
--   the specified string in the part of web requests that you specified in
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt>. The maximum length of the value is 50 bytes.
--   
--   Valid values depend on the values that you specified for
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>HEADER</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search for in
--   the request header that you specified in FieldToMatch, for example,
--   the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt> header.</li>
--   <li><tt>METHOD</tt>: The HTTP method, which indicates the type of
--   operation specified in the request. CloudFront supports the following
--   methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>, <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>,
--   <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and
--   <tt>PUT</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search
--   for in the query string, which is the part of a URL that appears after
--   a <tt>?</tt> character.</li>
--   <li><tt>URI</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search for in the
--   part of a URL that identifies a resource, for example,
--   <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>BODY</tt>: The part of a request that contains any additional
--   data that you want to send to your web server as the HTTP request
--   body, such as data from a form. The request body immediately follows
--   the request headers. Note that only the first <tt>8192</tt> bytes of
--   the request body are forwarded to AWS WAF for inspection. To allow or
--   block requests based on the length of the body, you can create a size
--   constraint set. For more information, see
--   CreateSizeConstraintSet.</li>
--   <li><tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>: The parameter in the query string that
--   you will inspect, such as <i>UserName</i> or <i>SalesRegion</i>. The
--   maximum length for <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt> is 30 characters.</li>
--   <li><tt>ALL_QUERY_ARGS</tt>: Similar to <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, but
--   instead of inspecting a single parameter, AWS WAF inspects all
--   parameters within the query string for the value or regex pattern that
--   you specify in <tt>TargetString</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>TargetString</tt> includes alphabetic characters A-Z and a-z,
--   note that the value is case sensitive.
--   
--   <b>If you're using the AWS WAF API</b>
--   
--   Specify a base64-encoded version of the value. The maximum length of
--   the value before you base64-encode it is 50 bytes.
--   
--   For example, suppose the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>HEADER</tt> and
--   the value of <tt>Data</tt> is <tt>User-Agent</tt>. If you want to
--   search the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header for the value <tt>BadBot</tt>,
--   you base64-encode <tt>BadBot</tt> using MIME base64-encoding and
--   include the resulting value, <tt>QmFkQm90</tt>, in the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <b>If you're using the AWS CLI or one of the AWS SDKs</b>
--   
--   The value that you want AWS WAF to search for. The SDK automatically
--   base64 encodes the value.
[$sel:targetString:ByteMatchTuple'] :: ByteMatchTuple -> Base64

-- | Text transformations eliminate some of the unusual formatting that
--   attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF. If you
--   specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt> before inspecting it for a match.
--   
--   You can only specify a single type of TextTransformation.
--   
--   <b>CMD_LINE</b>
--   
--   When you're concerned that attackers are injecting an operating system
--   command line command and using unusual formatting to disguise some or
--   all of the command, use this option to perform the following
--   transformations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Delete the following characters: \ " ' ^</li>
--   <li>Delete spaces before the following characters: / (</li>
--   <li>Replace the following characters with a space: , ;</li>
--   <li>Replace multiple spaces with one space</li>
--   <li>Convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace the following characters with a space
--   character (decimal 32):
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>\f, formfeed, decimal 12</li>
--   <li>\t, tab, decimal 9</li>
--   <li>\n, newline, decimal 10</li>
--   <li>\r, carriage return, decimal 13</li>
--   <li>\v, vertical tab, decimal 11</li>
--   <li>non-breaking space, decimal 160</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</tt> also replaces multiple spaces with one
--   space.
--   
--   <b>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace HTML-encoded characters with unencoded
--   characters. <tt>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</tt> performs the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)quot;</tt> with <tt>"</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)nbsp;</tt> with a non-breaking space,
--   decimal 160</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)lt;</tt> with a "less than" symbol</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)gt;</tt> with <tt>&gt;</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in hexadecimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#xhhhh;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in decimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#nnnn;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>LOWERCASE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z).
--   
--   <b>URL_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to decode a URL-encoded value.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>
--   
--   Specify <tt>NONE</tt> if you don't want to perform any text
--   transformations.
[$sel:textTransformation:ByteMatchTuple'] :: ByteMatchTuple -> TextTransformation

-- | Within the portion of a web request that you want to search (for
--   example, in the query string, if any), specify where you want AWS WAF
--   to search. Valid values include the following:
--   
--   <b>CONTAINS</b>
--   
--   The specified part of the web request must include the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>, but the location doesn't matter.
--   
--   <b>CONTAINS_WORD</b>
--   
--   The specified part of the web request must include the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>, and <tt>TargetString</tt> must contain only
--   alphanumeric characters or underscore (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, or _). In
--   addition, <tt>TargetString</tt> must be a word, which means one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> exactly matches the value of the specified
--   part of the web request, such as the value of a header.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is at the beginning of the specified part of
--   the web request and is followed by a character other than an
--   alphanumeric character or underscore (_), for example,
--   <tt>BadBot;</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is at the end of the specified part of the
--   web request and is preceded by a character other than an alphanumeric
--   character or underscore (_), for example, <tt>;BadBot</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is in the middle of the specified part of
--   the web request and is preceded and followed by characters other than
--   alphanumeric characters or underscore (_), for example,
--   <tt>-BadBot;</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>EXACTLY</b>
--   
--   The value of the specified part of the web request must exactly match
--   the value of <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <b>STARTS_WITH</b>
--   
--   The value of <tt>TargetString</tt> must appear at the beginning of the
--   specified part of the web request.
--   
--   <b>ENDS_WITH</b>
--   
--   The value of <tt>TargetString</tt> must appear at the end of the
--   specified part of the web request.
[$sel:positionalConstraint:ByteMatchTuple'] :: ByteMatchTuple -> PositionalConstraint

-- | Create a value of <a>ByteMatchTuple</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:fieldToMatch:ByteMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchTuple_fieldToMatch</a> - The part of a web request that
--   you want AWS WAF to search, such as a specified header or a query
--   string. For more information, see FieldToMatch.
--   
--   <a>$sel:targetString:ByteMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchTuple_targetString</a> - The value that you want AWS WAF
--   to search for. AWS WAF searches for the specified string in the part
--   of web requests that you specified in <tt>FieldToMatch</tt>. The
--   maximum length of the value is 50 bytes.
--   
--   Valid values depend on the values that you specified for
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>HEADER</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search for in
--   the request header that you specified in FieldToMatch, for example,
--   the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt> header.</li>
--   <li><tt>METHOD</tt>: The HTTP method, which indicates the type of
--   operation specified in the request. CloudFront supports the following
--   methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>, <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>,
--   <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and
--   <tt>PUT</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search
--   for in the query string, which is the part of a URL that appears after
--   a <tt>?</tt> character.</li>
--   <li><tt>URI</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search for in the
--   part of a URL that identifies a resource, for example,
--   <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>BODY</tt>: The part of a request that contains any additional
--   data that you want to send to your web server as the HTTP request
--   body, such as data from a form. The request body immediately follows
--   the request headers. Note that only the first <tt>8192</tt> bytes of
--   the request body are forwarded to AWS WAF for inspection. To allow or
--   block requests based on the length of the body, you can create a size
--   constraint set. For more information, see
--   CreateSizeConstraintSet.</li>
--   <li><tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>: The parameter in the query string that
--   you will inspect, such as <i>UserName</i> or <i>SalesRegion</i>. The
--   maximum length for <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt> is 30 characters.</li>
--   <li><tt>ALL_QUERY_ARGS</tt>: Similar to <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, but
--   instead of inspecting a single parameter, AWS WAF inspects all
--   parameters within the query string for the value or regex pattern that
--   you specify in <tt>TargetString</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>TargetString</tt> includes alphabetic characters A-Z and a-z,
--   note that the value is case sensitive.
--   
--   <b>If you're using the AWS WAF API</b>
--   
--   Specify a base64-encoded version of the value. The maximum length of
--   the value before you base64-encode it is 50 bytes.
--   
--   For example, suppose the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>HEADER</tt> and
--   the value of <tt>Data</tt> is <tt>User-Agent</tt>. If you want to
--   search the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header for the value <tt>BadBot</tt>,
--   you base64-encode <tt>BadBot</tt> using MIME base64-encoding and
--   include the resulting value, <tt>QmFkQm90</tt>, in the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <b>If you're using the AWS CLI or one of the AWS SDKs</b>
--   
--   The value that you want AWS WAF to search for. The SDK automatically
--   base64 encodes the value.-- -- <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt>
--   automatically encodes and decodes Base64 data. -- The underlying
--   isomorphism will encode to Base64 representation during --
--   serialisation, and decode from Base64 representation during
--   deserialisation. -- This <tt>Lens</tt> accepts and returns only raw
--   unencoded data.
--   
--   <a>$sel:textTransformation:ByteMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchTuple_textTransformation</a> - Text transformations
--   eliminate some of the unusual formatting that attackers use in web
--   requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF. If you specify a
--   transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt> before inspecting it for a match.
--   
--   You can only specify a single type of TextTransformation.
--   
--   <b>CMD_LINE</b>
--   
--   When you're concerned that attackers are injecting an operating system
--   command line command and using unusual formatting to disguise some or
--   all of the command, use this option to perform the following
--   transformations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Delete the following characters: \ " ' ^</li>
--   <li>Delete spaces before the following characters: / (</li>
--   <li>Replace the following characters with a space: , ;</li>
--   <li>Replace multiple spaces with one space</li>
--   <li>Convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace the following characters with a space
--   character (decimal 32):
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>\f, formfeed, decimal 12</li>
--   <li>\t, tab, decimal 9</li>
--   <li>\n, newline, decimal 10</li>
--   <li>\r, carriage return, decimal 13</li>
--   <li>\v, vertical tab, decimal 11</li>
--   <li>non-breaking space, decimal 160</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</tt> also replaces multiple spaces with one
--   space.
--   
--   <b>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace HTML-encoded characters with unencoded
--   characters. <tt>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</tt> performs the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)quot;</tt> with <tt>"</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)nbsp;</tt> with a non-breaking space,
--   decimal 160</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)lt;</tt> with a "less than" symbol</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)gt;</tt> with <tt>&gt;</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in hexadecimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#xhhhh;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in decimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#nnnn;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>LOWERCASE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z).
--   
--   <b>URL_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to decode a URL-encoded value.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>
--   
--   Specify <tt>NONE</tt> if you don't want to perform any text
--   transformations.
--   
--   <a>$sel:positionalConstraint:ByteMatchTuple'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchTuple_positionalConstraint</a> - Within the portion of a
--   web request that you want to search (for example, in the query string,
--   if any), specify where you want AWS WAF to search. Valid values
--   include the following:
--   
--   <b>CONTAINS</b>
--   
--   The specified part of the web request must include the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>, but the location doesn't matter.
--   
--   <b>CONTAINS_WORD</b>
--   
--   The specified part of the web request must include the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>, and <tt>TargetString</tt> must contain only
--   alphanumeric characters or underscore (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, or _). In
--   addition, <tt>TargetString</tt> must be a word, which means one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> exactly matches the value of the specified
--   part of the web request, such as the value of a header.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is at the beginning of the specified part of
--   the web request and is followed by a character other than an
--   alphanumeric character or underscore (_), for example,
--   <tt>BadBot;</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is at the end of the specified part of the
--   web request and is preceded by a character other than an alphanumeric
--   character or underscore (_), for example, <tt>;BadBot</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is in the middle of the specified part of
--   the web request and is preceded and followed by characters other than
--   alphanumeric characters or underscore (_), for example,
--   <tt>-BadBot;</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>EXACTLY</b>
--   
--   The value of the specified part of the web request must exactly match
--   the value of <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <b>STARTS_WITH</b>
--   
--   The value of <tt>TargetString</tt> must appear at the beginning of the
--   specified part of the web request.
--   
--   <b>ENDS_WITH</b>
--   
--   The value of <tt>TargetString</tt> must appear at the end of the
--   specified part of the web request.
newByteMatchTuple :: FieldToMatch -> ByteString -> TextTransformation -> PositionalConstraint -> ByteMatchTuple

-- | The part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to search, such as a
--   specified header or a query string. For more information, see
--   FieldToMatch.
byteMatchTuple_fieldToMatch :: Lens' ByteMatchTuple FieldToMatch

-- | The value that you want AWS WAF to search for. AWS WAF searches for
--   the specified string in the part of web requests that you specified in
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt>. The maximum length of the value is 50 bytes.
--   
--   Valid values depend on the values that you specified for
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt>:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>HEADER</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search for in
--   the request header that you specified in FieldToMatch, for example,
--   the value of the <tt>User-Agent</tt> or <tt>Referer</tt> header.</li>
--   <li><tt>METHOD</tt>: The HTTP method, which indicates the type of
--   operation specified in the request. CloudFront supports the following
--   methods: <tt>DELETE</tt>, <tt>GET</tt>, <tt>HEAD</tt>,
--   <tt>OPTIONS</tt>, <tt>PATCH</tt>, <tt>POST</tt>, and
--   <tt>PUT</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>QUERY_STRING</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search
--   for in the query string, which is the part of a URL that appears after
--   a <tt>?</tt> character.</li>
--   <li><tt>URI</tt>: The value that you want AWS WAF to search for in the
--   part of a URL that identifies a resource, for example,
--   <tt>/images/daily-ad.jpg</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>BODY</tt>: The part of a request that contains any additional
--   data that you want to send to your web server as the HTTP request
--   body, such as data from a form. The request body immediately follows
--   the request headers. Note that only the first <tt>8192</tt> bytes of
--   the request body are forwarded to AWS WAF for inspection. To allow or
--   block requests based on the length of the body, you can create a size
--   constraint set. For more information, see
--   CreateSizeConstraintSet.</li>
--   <li><tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>: The parameter in the query string that
--   you will inspect, such as <i>UserName</i> or <i>SalesRegion</i>. The
--   maximum length for <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt> is 30 characters.</li>
--   <li><tt>ALL_QUERY_ARGS</tt>: Similar to <tt>SINGLE_QUERY_ARG</tt>, but
--   instead of inspecting a single parameter, AWS WAF inspects all
--   parameters within the query string for the value or regex pattern that
--   you specify in <tt>TargetString</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   If <tt>TargetString</tt> includes alphabetic characters A-Z and a-z,
--   note that the value is case sensitive.
--   
--   <b>If you're using the AWS WAF API</b>
--   
--   Specify a base64-encoded version of the value. The maximum length of
--   the value before you base64-encode it is 50 bytes.
--   
--   For example, suppose the value of <tt>Type</tt> is <tt>HEADER</tt> and
--   the value of <tt>Data</tt> is <tt>User-Agent</tt>. If you want to
--   search the <tt>User-Agent</tt> header for the value <tt>BadBot</tt>,
--   you base64-encode <tt>BadBot</tt> using MIME base64-encoding and
--   include the resulting value, <tt>QmFkQm90</tt>, in the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <b>If you're using the AWS CLI or one of the AWS SDKs</b>
--   
--   The value that you want AWS WAF to search for. The SDK automatically
--   base64 encodes the value.-- -- <i>Note:</i> This <tt>Lens</tt>
--   automatically encodes and decodes Base64 data. -- The underlying
--   isomorphism will encode to Base64 representation during --
--   serialisation, and decode from Base64 representation during
--   deserialisation. -- This <tt>Lens</tt> accepts and returns only raw
--   unencoded data.
byteMatchTuple_targetString :: Lens' ByteMatchTuple ByteString

-- | Text transformations eliminate some of the unusual formatting that
--   attackers use in web requests in an effort to bypass AWS WAF. If you
--   specify a transformation, AWS WAF performs the transformation on
--   <tt>FieldToMatch</tt> before inspecting it for a match.
--   
--   You can only specify a single type of TextTransformation.
--   
--   <b>CMD_LINE</b>
--   
--   When you're concerned that attackers are injecting an operating system
--   command line command and using unusual formatting to disguise some or
--   all of the command, use this option to perform the following
--   transformations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Delete the following characters: \ " ' ^</li>
--   <li>Delete spaces before the following characters: / (</li>
--   <li>Replace the following characters with a space: , ;</li>
--   <li>Replace multiple spaces with one space</li>
--   <li>Convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z)</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace the following characters with a space
--   character (decimal 32):
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>\f, formfeed, decimal 12</li>
--   <li>\t, tab, decimal 9</li>
--   <li>\n, newline, decimal 10</li>
--   <li>\r, carriage return, decimal 13</li>
--   <li>\v, vertical tab, decimal 11</li>
--   <li>non-breaking space, decimal 160</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <tt>COMPRESS_WHITE_SPACE</tt> also replaces multiple spaces with one
--   space.
--   
--   <b>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to replace HTML-encoded characters with unencoded
--   characters. <tt>HTML_ENTITY_DECODE</tt> performs the following
--   operations:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)quot;</tt> with <tt>"</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)nbsp;</tt> with a non-breaking space,
--   decimal 160</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)lt;</tt> with a "less than" symbol</li>
--   <li>Replaces <tt>(ampersand)gt;</tt> with <tt>&gt;</tt></li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in hexadecimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#xhhhh;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   <li>Replaces characters that are represented in decimal format,
--   <tt>(ampersand)#nnnn;</tt>, with the corresponding characters</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>LOWERCASE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to convert uppercase letters (A-Z) to lowercase (a-z).
--   
--   <b>URL_DECODE</b>
--   
--   Use this option to decode a URL-encoded value.
--   
--   <b>NONE</b>
--   
--   Specify <tt>NONE</tt> if you don't want to perform any text
--   transformations.
byteMatchTuple_textTransformation :: Lens' ByteMatchTuple TextTransformation

-- | Within the portion of a web request that you want to search (for
--   example, in the query string, if any), specify where you want AWS WAF
--   to search. Valid values include the following:
--   
--   <b>CONTAINS</b>
--   
--   The specified part of the web request must include the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>, but the location doesn't matter.
--   
--   <b>CONTAINS_WORD</b>
--   
--   The specified part of the web request must include the value of
--   <tt>TargetString</tt>, and <tt>TargetString</tt> must contain only
--   alphanumeric characters or underscore (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, or _). In
--   addition, <tt>TargetString</tt> must be a word, which means one of the
--   following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> exactly matches the value of the specified
--   part of the web request, such as the value of a header.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is at the beginning of the specified part of
--   the web request and is followed by a character other than an
--   alphanumeric character or underscore (_), for example,
--   <tt>BadBot;</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is at the end of the specified part of the
--   web request and is preceded by a character other than an alphanumeric
--   character or underscore (_), for example, <tt>;BadBot</tt>.</li>
--   <li><tt>TargetString</tt> is in the middle of the specified part of
--   the web request and is preceded and followed by characters other than
--   alphanumeric characters or underscore (_), for example,
--   <tt>-BadBot;</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
--   
--   <b>EXACTLY</b>
--   
--   The value of the specified part of the web request must exactly match
--   the value of <tt>TargetString</tt>.
--   
--   <b>STARTS_WITH</b>
--   
--   The value of <tt>TargetString</tt> must appear at the beginning of the
--   specified part of the web request.
--   
--   <b>ENDS_WITH</b>
--   
--   The value of <tt>TargetString</tt> must appear at the end of the
--   specified part of the web request.
byteMatchTuple_positionalConstraint :: Lens' ByteMatchTuple PositionalConstraint
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchTuple.ByteMatchTuple


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   In an UpdateByteMatchSet request, <tt>ByteMatchSetUpdate</tt>
--   specifies whether to insert or delete a ByteMatchTuple and includes
--   the settings for the <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newByteMatchSetUpdate</a> smart constructor.
data ByteMatchSetUpdate
ByteMatchSetUpdate' :: ChangeAction -> ByteMatchTuple -> ByteMatchSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a ByteMatchTuple.
[$sel:action:ByteMatchSetUpdate'] :: ByteMatchSetUpdate -> ChangeAction

-- | Information about the part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to
--   inspect and the value that you want AWS WAF to search for. If you
--   specify <tt>DELETE</tt> for the value of <tt>Action</tt>, the
--   <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> values must exactly match the values in the
--   <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> that you want to delete from the
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
[$sel:byteMatchTuple:ByteMatchSetUpdate'] :: ByteMatchSetUpdate -> ByteMatchTuple

-- | Create a value of <a>ByteMatchSetUpdate</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:action:ByteMatchSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchSetUpdate_action</a> - Specifies whether to insert or
--   delete a ByteMatchTuple.
--   
--   <a>$sel:byteMatchTuple:ByteMatchSetUpdate'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchSetUpdate_byteMatchTuple</a> - Information about the part
--   of a web request that you want AWS WAF to inspect and the value that
--   you want AWS WAF to search for. If you specify <tt>DELETE</tt> for the
--   value of <tt>Action</tt>, the <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> values must
--   exactly match the values in the <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> that you want
--   to delete from the <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
newByteMatchSetUpdate :: ChangeAction -> ByteMatchTuple -> ByteMatchSetUpdate

-- | Specifies whether to insert or delete a ByteMatchTuple.
byteMatchSetUpdate_action :: Lens' ByteMatchSetUpdate ChangeAction

-- | Information about the part of a web request that you want AWS WAF to
--   inspect and the value that you want AWS WAF to search for. If you
--   specify <tt>DELETE</tt> for the value of <tt>Action</tt>, the
--   <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> values must exactly match the values in the
--   <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> that you want to delete from the
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
byteMatchSetUpdate_byteMatchTuple :: Lens' ByteMatchSetUpdate ByteMatchTuple
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSetUpdate.ByteMatchSetUpdate


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   In a GetByteMatchSet request, <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> is a complex type
--   that contains the <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> and <tt>Name</tt> of a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>, and the values that you specified when you
--   updated the <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
--   
--   A complex type that contains <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> objects, which
--   specify the parts of web requests that you want AWS WAF to inspect and
--   the values that you want AWS WAF to search for. If a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> contains more than one <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt>
--   object, a request needs to match the settings in only one
--   <tt>ByteMatchTuple</tt> to be considered a match.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newByteMatchSet</a> smart constructor.
data ByteMatchSet
ByteMatchSet' :: Maybe Text -> Text -> [ByteMatchTuple] -> ByteMatchSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the ByteMatchSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
[$sel:name:ByteMatchSet'] :: ByteMatchSet -> Maybe Text

-- | The <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> for a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> (see GetByteMatchSet), update a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateByteMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>
--   from AWS WAF (see DeleteByteMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateByteMatchSet and by
--   ListByteMatchSets.
[$sel:byteMatchSetId:ByteMatchSet'] :: ByteMatchSet -> Text

-- | Specifies the bytes (typically a string that corresponds with ASCII
--   characters) that you want AWS WAF to search for in web requests, the
--   location in requests that you want AWS WAF to search, and other
--   settings.
[$sel:byteMatchTuples:ByteMatchSet'] :: ByteMatchSet -> [ByteMatchTuple]

-- | Create a value of <a>ByteMatchSet</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:name:ByteMatchSet'</a>, <a>byteMatchSet_name</a> - A friendly
--   name or description of the ByteMatchSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
--   
--   <a>$sel:byteMatchSetId:ByteMatchSet'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchSet_byteMatchSetId</a> - The <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> for a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>. You use <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> to get
--   information about a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> (see GetByteMatchSet),
--   update a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateByteMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>
--   from AWS WAF (see DeleteByteMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateByteMatchSet and by
--   ListByteMatchSets.
--   
--   <a>$sel:byteMatchTuples:ByteMatchSet'</a>,
--   <a>byteMatchSet_byteMatchTuples</a> - Specifies the bytes (typically a
--   string that corresponds with ASCII characters) that you want AWS WAF
--   to search for in web requests, the location in requests that you want
--   AWS WAF to search, and other settings.
newByteMatchSet :: Text -> ByteMatchSet

-- | A friendly name or description of the ByteMatchSet. You can't change
--   <tt>Name</tt> after you create a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>.
byteMatchSet_name :: Lens' ByteMatchSet (Maybe Text)

-- | The <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> for a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>. You use
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> to get information about a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> (see GetByteMatchSet), update a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> (see UpdateByteMatchSet), insert a
--   <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt> into a <tt>Rule</tt> or delete one from a
--   <tt>Rule</tt> (see UpdateRule), and delete a <tt>ByteMatchSet</tt>
--   from AWS WAF (see DeleteByteMatchSet).
--   
--   <tt>ByteMatchSetId</tt> is returned by CreateByteMatchSet and by
--   ListByteMatchSets.
byteMatchSet_byteMatchSetId :: Lens' ByteMatchSet Text

-- | Specifies the bytes (typically a string that corresponds with ASCII
--   characters) that you want AWS WAF to search for in web requests, the
--   location in requests that you want AWS WAF to search, and other
--   settings.
byteMatchSet_byteMatchTuples :: Lens' ByteMatchSet [ByteMatchTuple]
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.ByteMatchSet.ByteMatchSet


module Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   In a GetSampledRequests request, the <tt>StartTime</tt> and
--   <tt>EndTime</tt> objects specify the time range for which you want AWS
--   WAF to return a sample of web requests.
--   
--   You must specify the times in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) format.
--   UTC format includes the special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>.
--   
--   In a GetSampledRequests response, the <tt>StartTime</tt> and
--   <tt>EndTime</tt> objects specify the time range for which AWS WAF
--   actually returned a sample of web requests. AWS WAF gets the specified
--   number of requests from among the first 5,000 requests that your AWS
--   resource receives during the specified time period. If your resource
--   receives more than 5,000 requests during that period, AWS WAF stops
--   sampling after the 5,000th request. In that case, <tt>EndTime</tt> is
--   the time that AWS WAF received the 5,000th request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newTimeWindow</a> smart constructor.
data TimeWindow
TimeWindow' :: POSIX -> POSIX -> TimeWindow

-- | The beginning of the time range from which you want
--   <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt> to return a sample of the requests that
--   your AWS resource received. You must specify the date and time in
--   Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) format. UTC format includes the
--   special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>. You can specify any time range in the
--   previous three hours.
[$sel:startTime:TimeWindow'] :: TimeWindow -> POSIX

-- | The end of the time range from which you want
--   <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt> to return a sample of the requests that
--   your AWS resource received. You must specify the date and time in
--   Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) format. UTC format includes the
--   special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>. You can specify any time range in the
--   previous three hours.
[$sel:endTime:TimeWindow'] :: TimeWindow -> POSIX

-- | Create a value of <a>TimeWindow</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:startTime:TimeWindow'</a>, <a>timeWindow_startTime</a> - The
--   beginning of the time range from which you want
--   <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt> to return a sample of the requests that
--   your AWS resource received. You must specify the date and time in
--   Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) format. UTC format includes the
--   special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>. You can specify any time range in the
--   previous three hours.
--   
--   <a>$sel:endTime:TimeWindow'</a>, <a>timeWindow_endTime</a> - The end
--   of the time range from which you want <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt> to
--   return a sample of the requests that your AWS resource received. You
--   must specify the date and time in Coordinated Universal Time (UTC)
--   format. UTC format includes the special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For
--   example, <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>. You can specify any time range
--   in the previous three hours.
newTimeWindow :: UTCTime -> UTCTime -> TimeWindow

-- | The beginning of the time range from which you want
--   <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt> to return a sample of the requests that
--   your AWS resource received. You must specify the date and time in
--   Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) format. UTC format includes the
--   special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>. You can specify any time range in the
--   previous three hours.
timeWindow_startTime :: Lens' TimeWindow UTCTime

-- | The end of the time range from which you want
--   <tt>GetSampledRequests</tt> to return a sample of the requests that
--   your AWS resource received. You must specify the date and time in
--   Coordinated Universal Time (UTC) format. UTC format includes the
--   special designator, <tt>Z</tt>. For example,
--   <tt>"2016-09-27T14:50Z"</tt>. You can specify any time range in the
--   previous three hours.
timeWindow_endTime :: Lens' TimeWindow UTCTime
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.TimeWindow.TimeWindow

WafActionType' :: Text -> WafActionType
[fromWafActionType] :: WafActionType -> Text
pattern WafActionType_ALLOW :: WafActionType

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   For the action that is associated with a rule in a <tt>WebACL</tt>,
--   specifies the action that you want AWS WAF to perform when a web
--   request matches all of the conditions in a rule. For the default
--   action in a <tt>WebACL</tt>, specifies the action that you want AWS
--   WAF to take when a web request doesn't match all of the conditions in
--   any of the rules in a <tt>WebACL</tt>.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newWafAction</a> smart constructor.
data WafAction
WafAction' :: WafActionType -> WafAction

-- | Specifies how you want AWS WAF to respond to requests that match the
--   settings in a <tt>Rule</tt>. Valid settings include the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALLOW</tt>: AWS WAF allows requests</li>
--   <li><tt>BLOCK</tt>: AWS WAF blocks requests</li>
--   <li><tt>COUNT</tt>: AWS WAF increments a counter of the requests that
--   match all of the conditions in the rule. AWS WAF then continues to
--   inspect the web request based on the remaining rules in the web ACL.
--   You can't specify <tt>COUNT</tt> for the default action for a
--   <tt>WebACL</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
[$sel:type':WafAction'] :: WafAction -> WafActionType

-- | Create a value of <a>WafAction</a> with all optional fields omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':WafAction'</a>, <a>wafAction_type</a> - Specifies how
--   you want AWS WAF to respond to requests that match the settings in a
--   <tt>Rule</tt>. Valid settings include the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALLOW</tt>: AWS WAF allows requests</li>
--   <li><tt>BLOCK</tt>: AWS WAF blocks requests</li>
--   <li><tt>COUNT</tt>: AWS WAF increments a counter of the requests that
--   match all of the conditions in the rule. AWS WAF then continues to
--   inspect the web request based on the remaining rules in the web ACL.
--   You can't specify <tt>COUNT</tt> for the default action for a
--   <tt>WebACL</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
newWafAction :: WafActionType -> WafAction

-- | Specifies how you want AWS WAF to respond to requests that match the
--   settings in a <tt>Rule</tt>. Valid settings include the following:
--   
--   <ul>
--   <li><tt>ALLOW</tt>: AWS WAF allows requests</li>
--   <li><tt>BLOCK</tt>: AWS WAF blocks requests</li>
--   <li><tt>COUNT</tt>: AWS WAF increments a counter of the requests that
--   match all of the conditions in the rule. AWS WAF then continues to
--   inspect the web request based on the remaining rules in the web ACL.
--   You can't specify <tt>COUNT</tt> for the default action for a
--   <tt>WebACL</tt>.</li>
--   </ul>
wafAction_type :: Lens' WafAction WafActionType
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafAction.WafAction

module Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction

-- | This is <b>AWS WAF Classic</b> documentation. For more information,
--   see <a>AWS WAF Classic</a> in the developer guide.
--   
--   <b>For the latest version of AWS WAF</b>, use the AWS WAFV2 API and
--   see the <a>AWS WAF Developer Guide</a>. With the latest version, AWS
--   WAF has a single set of endpoints for regional and global use.
--   
--   The action to take if any rule within the <tt>RuleGroup</tt> matches a
--   request.
--   
--   <i>See:</i> <a>newWafOverrideAction</a> smart constructor.
data WafOverrideAction
WafOverrideAction' :: WafOverrideActionType -> WafOverrideAction

-- | <tt>COUNT</tt> overrides the action specified by the individual rule
--   within a <tt>RuleGroup</tt> . If set to <tt>NONE</tt>, the rule's
--   action will take place.
[$sel:type':WafOverrideAction'] :: WafOverrideAction -> WafOverrideActionType

-- | Create a value of <a>WafOverrideAction</a> with all optional fields
--   omitted.
--   
--   Use <a>generic-lens</a> or <a>optics</a> to modify other optional
--   fields.
--   
--   The following record fields are available, with the corresponding
--   lenses provided for backwards compatibility:
--   
--   <a>$sel:type':WafOverrideAction'</a>, <a>wafOverrideAction_type</a> -
--   <tt>COUNT</tt> overrides the action specified by the individual rule
--   within a <tt>RuleGroup</tt> . If set to <tt>NONE</tt>, the rule's
--   action will take place.
newWafOverrideAction :: WafOverrideActionType -> WafOverrideAction

-- | <tt>COUNT</tt> overrides the action specified by the individual rule
--   within a <tt>RuleGroup</tt> . If set to <tt>NONE</tt>, the rule's
--   action will take place.
wafOverrideAction_type :: Lens' WafOverrideAction WafOverrideActionType
instance GHC.Generics.Generic Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance GHC.Show.Show Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance GHC.Read.Read Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance GHC.Classes.Eq Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance Data.Aeson.Types.FromJSON.FromJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance Data.Hashable.Class.Hashable Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance Control.DeepSeq.NFData Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
instance Data.Aeson.Types.ToJSON.ToJSON Amazonka.WAF.Types.WafOverrideAction.WafOverrideAction
